lens.lens_summary: Kahneman's Two Selves framework (Part V of Thinking, Fast and Slow) reveals that the guest's decision to rebook on Split Lease is governed not by the totality of their lived experience during the lease, but by the remembering self's distorted summary of it. The peak-end rule means the most intense moment (positive or negative) and the final moment of the stay disproportionately determine the guest's retrospective evaluation. Duration neglect means a 16-week lease is remembered no differently than a 4-week lease -- only the peaks and the ending matter. The focusing illusion means that whatever the guest is attending to at the moment of evaluation (move-in shock, a dispute, a beautiful space) will loom larger than it deserves. Together, these principles reveal that Split Lease's retention problem is not about the average quality of the experience but about the architecture of memorable moments -- particularly move-in (first peak) and the final days of the lease (the end that defines the memory).

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Discovery is where the guest's remembering self encounters Split Lease for the first time and begins constructing a proto-narrative. Kahneman Ch 36 establishes that 'a story is about significant events and memorable moments, not about time passing' -- the guest in discovery is not conducting a systematic evaluation but collecting fragments that will form a story about whether this platform is worth trusting. The user stories analysis confirms: 'Value before the ask -- always. Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them.' This is a focusing illusion problem: whatever the guest encounters first in discovery will loom disproportionately large in their evaluation of the platform. If the first impression is a cluttered landing page or a demand for personal information, that becomes the 'peak' of the discovery experience -- and the peak-end rule ensures it defines the entire remembered impression. Conversely, if the first impression is a beautiful listing card with a photo carousel (user stories: 'each listing card to show a photo carousel with navigation arrows'), the positive peak anchors the nascent narrative. The existing library addresses trust gates and first impressions, but the Two Selves lens adds a specific mechanism: discovery is not about what the guest learns, it is about what memorable fragment the remembering self captures and stores as representative of the entire platform.

user_state.emotional_state: Curious but uncommitted. The experiencing self is browsing -- moment-to-moment engagement is low-stakes and exploratory. The remembering self, however, is already composing: it will retain only the most vivid fragment of this encounter. Kahneman Ch 35: 'Memories are all we get to keep from our experience of living, and the only perspective that we can adopt as we think about our lives is therefore that of the remembering self.' If the guest leaves discovery and returns days later, they will not remember the browsing -- only the peak impression.
user_state.knowledge_level: Minimal. The guest may have found Split Lease through search, referral, or social media. They do not yet understand how the platform works, what proposals are, or what a split lease means. Their knowledge is a single vivid impression, not a comprehensive understanding.
user_state.commitment_level: None. The guest has invested nothing. The experiencing self is in a neutral state that Kahneman would characterize as 'not caring either way' -- neither wanting to continue nor wanting to stop. This neutrality is dangerous because it means no positive peak is being created.
user_state.data_available: Landing page visit, referral source, time on page, scroll depth, first interaction (if any). The platform knows almost nothing about this person.

reasons: No positive peak has been created yet -- the remembering self has nothing compelling to store
The focusing illusion means any negative first impression (confusing UI, information demand, slow loading) will define the entire platform in memory
Duration neglect works against the platform: a guest who spends 10 minutes browsing but encounters one confusing moment will remember only the confusion
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.' Kahneman Ch 38: 'Nothing in life is as important as you think it is when you are thinking about it' -- in discovery, whatever the guest is thinking about IS the platform. A single negative focal point becomes the entire evaluation.

key_quotes.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
key_quotes.relevance: The remembering self stores the first significant moment. If that moment is a demand for information rather than a display of value, the peak of the discovery narrative is negative. The guest who returns to consider Split Lease later will recall only the demand, not whatever value came after.

key_quotes.quote: Nothing in life is as important as you think it is when you are thinking about it.
key_quotes.relevance: In discovery, the guest is thinking about exactly one thing: whatever the platform showed them first. The focusing illusion inflates this single impression into a global evaluation. The platform must ensure this first moment is a positive peak, not a neutral or negative one.

search.what_this_lens_reveals: Search is the phase where the experiencing self is most active -- the guest is moment-to-moment engaged with listings, filters, and map interactions. But Kahneman's framework warns that none of this moment-to-moment browsing will be retained by the remembering self in proportion to time spent. The guest who spends 45 minutes searching and finds one stunning listing will remember only the stunning listing. The guest who spends 45 minutes and encounters frustration (bad filters, irrelevant results, confusing UI) will remember only the frustration. Duration neglect means the length of the search session is irrelevant to the remembered experience -- only the peak (best or worst listing encountered) and the end (what they saw last) matter. The user stories analysis identifies specific mechanisms for creating positive peaks during search: 'each listing card to show a photo carousel with navigation arrows so that I preview multiple images without leaving search results' and 'the map to show transit stops, landmarks, and points of interest.' These are peak-manufacturing features: they increase the probability that the guest encounters a vivid, positive moment that the remembering self will store. The existing library addresses search UX, but the Two Selves lens reframes the goal: search design is not about optimizing average experience, it is about maximizing the probability of a positive peak and ensuring the search session ends well.

user_state.emotional_state: Engaged and comparative. The experiencing self is actively evaluating -- each listing produces a momentary emotional response (interest, disappointment, excitement, skepticism). The remembering self is not tracking these moment-to-moment responses; it is waiting for a peak. Kahneman Ch 35: 'System 1 represents sets by averages, norms, and prototypes, not by sums' -- the entire search session will be represented by one prototypical listing, not by the sum of all listings viewed.
user_state.knowledge_level: Growing. The guest is learning the platform's vocabulary (nightly rates, lease durations, days-of-week availability), the range of available spaces, and the price-quality landscape. But this learning is incidental to the peak-seeking behavior.
user_state.commitment_level: Low but rising. The guest has invested time (which they will not accurately value due to duration neglect) but no formal commitment. The transition to listing_evaluation requires a peak -- a listing compelling enough to click into.
user_state.data_available: Search queries, filter selections, listings viewed, time per listing card, map interactions, carousel engagement, scroll depth in results.

reasons: If no listing creates a positive peak, the entire search session will be remembered as fruitless regardless of how many listings were viewed
The peak-end rule means the last listing viewed before the guest leaves determines the memory of the search -- if the guest stops after a disappointing result, the entire session is colored negative
Duration neglect means the guest who spent 2 hours searching feels no more invested than one who spent 10 minutes, so time investment creates no retention
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Listing cards want more layers. The current card works but it's leaving engagement on the table. Richer hover states, image counters, availability indicators, neighborhood labels, and quick actions -- all without leaving the search grid.' Kahneman Ch 35: 'The global retrospective rating was well predicted by the average of the level of pain reported at the worst moment of the experience and at its end.' Applied to search: the retrospective rating of the search session is predicted by the best listing card encountered and the last one seen before exit.

key_quotes.quote: The current card works but it's leaving engagement on the table. Richer hover states, image counters, availability indicators, neighborhood labels, and quick actions -- all without leaving the search grid.
key_quotes.relevance: Richer listing cards increase the probability of a positive peak during search. Each additional layer of information and visual richness is an opportunity for the experiencing self to register a strong positive moment that the remembering self will store.

key_quotes.source: kahneman-part5-two-selves.txt, Ch 35 (Peak-end rule and Duration neglect)
key_quotes.quote: The global retrospective rating was well predicted by the average of the level of pain reported at the worst moment of the experience and at its end. Duration of the procedure had no effect whatsoever on the ratings of total pain.
key_quotes.relevance: Applied to search: the guest's memory of the search experience is predicted by the best/worst listing encounter and the final listing viewed. Session length is irrelevant. This means search design should optimize for peak moments and positive exits, not for comprehensiveness or time-on-site.

listing_evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: Listing evaluation is where the experiencing self and remembering self first diverge in ways that matter for the platform. The guest is moment-to-moment evaluating photos, price, rules, host info, and neighborhood -- the experiencing self is engaged. But the remembering self is already composing a story about this listing, and that story will be governed by the peak-end rule. Kahneman Ch 36: 'A story is about significant events and memorable moments, not about time passing.' The guest will not remember every photo or every rule; they will remember the most striking photo and the last piece of information they read before deciding. The user stories analysis identifies a critical mechanism: 'Messaging before proposals is a natural step. The park analogy holds -- you check availability before committing.' This is a Two Selves insight: the guest's experiencing self wants more information, but the remembering self needs a narrative bridge between 'I'm interested' and 'I'm committing.' Messaging creates a memorable interaction peak -- a human moment (asking the host a question) that the remembering self stores as evidence of connection and safety. Without it, the narrative jumps from 'I liked the photos' to 'I submitted a proposal,' which feels like a gap in the story. The focusing illusion also operates here: whatever the guest is attending to on the listing page becomes disproportionately important. If price is prominent, the guest evaluates the listing through a price lens. If photos are prominent, the evaluation shifts. The user stories note 'Verified reviews and host credibility signals activate guests' -- these are focusing mechanisms that direct attention to trust rather than price.

user_state.emotional_state: Deliberative but narrative-driven. The experiencing self is weighing specifics (price, location, amenities), but the remembering self is composing a story: 'I found a great place' or 'something felt off.' Kahneman Ch 36: 'we all care intensely for the narrative of our own life and very much want it to be a good story.' The guest wants the listing evaluation to be a discovery story, not a compromise story.
user_state.knowledge_level: High for this specific listing. The guest has absorbed photos, price, rules, and location. But their knowledge is filtered through the focusing illusion: whatever they attended to most closely defines their understanding of the listing, and everything else fades.
user_state.commitment_level: Medium. The guest has selected this listing from the search results (a choice that creates identification with it). They are psychologically leaning toward commitment but need the narrative to support it -- a credible host, reasonable rules, a 'this could work' feeling.
user_state.data_available: Listing page engagement: which photos viewed, time on page, which sections scrolled to, whether reviews were read, whether host profile was clicked, whether messaging was initiated.

reasons: The focusing illusion can turn a single negative detail (a bad photo, an unclear rule, missing reviews) into a deal-breaker that the remembering self stores as the defining characteristic of the listing
Without a messaging option, the guest who has questions has no way to create a positive human interaction peak -- they either commit with doubt or leave
The peak-end rule means the last thing the guest reads on the listing page (often rules or cancellation policy) disproportionately shapes their evaluation
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Messaging before proposals is a natural step. A message action reduces abandonment when someone isn't ready for a proposal. Having the option is better than having no action at all. Once someone messages a host, the path to a proposal gets shorter, not longer.' Kahneman Ch 38: 'Any aspect of life to which attention is directed will loom large in a global evaluation. This is the essence of the focusing illusion.' A missing review section or an unclear price breakdown will loom larger than the listing's actual qualities.

key_quotes.quote: A message action reduces abandonment when someone isn't ready for a proposal. Having the option is better than having no action at all. Once someone messages a host, the path to a proposal gets shorter, not longer.
key_quotes.relevance: Messaging creates a memorable interaction peak that the remembering self stores. The guest who messages a host has a richer narrative ('I reached out, the host responded, I felt good about it') than the guest who silently evaluates ('I looked at photos and guessed'). The richer narrative supports commitment.

key_quotes.quote: The frenetic picture taking of many tourists suggests that storing memories is often an important goal, which shapes both the plans for the vacation and the experience of it.
key_quotes.relevance: Applied to listing evaluation: the guest is not just evaluating the space for its experiential qualities but for its memorability -- 'will this be a good story to tell?' A listing with personality, unique features, and a responsive host creates a better prospective memory than a generic one, independent of actual livability.

proposal_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Proposal creation is an act of affective forecasting -- the guest is predicting how they will feel living in this space for the proposed duration. Kahneman Ch 38 introduces 'miswanting' (Daniel Gilbert's term): 'bad choices that arise from errors of affective forecasting.' The guest creating a proposal is susceptible to the focusing illusion: they are currently focused on the listing's best features (the photos, the location, the price) and will overweight these in predicting their future happiness. They are not thinking about the mundane reality of living there week after week -- duration neglect means they literally cannot imagine what 16 weeks will feel like differently from 4 weeks. The user stories analysis identifies that 'the proposal itself is a cross-activation event' and that structured, pre-populated proposals work better than blank forms. The Two Selves lens explains why: a pre-populated proposal gives the remembering self a coherent narrative of what was proposed, while a blank form forces the guest to construct the narrative themselves, increasing the risk of miswanting (choosing terms that sound good but will not produce good experiences). The journey map shows the guest configures duration, days per week, and sees calculated pricing. Each of these is an affective forecast: the guest imagines 16 weeks of Tuesday-Thursday stays and predicts satisfaction. But Kahneman warns that this prediction is driven by the focusing illusion -- the guest is thinking about the arrangement now, and 'nothing in life is as important as you think it is when you are thinking about it.'

user_state.emotional_state: Optimistically committed. The guest has decided this listing is right and is now constructing the terms of their stay. This is a peak moment of positive affect -- the anticipation of a new living arrangement. Kahneman Ch 38 (marriage graph): 'people who recently married, or are expecting to marry in the near future, are likely to retrieve that fact when asked a general question about their life.' Similarly, a guest creating a proposal is experiencing elevated satisfaction that will not persist at this intensity through the actual lease.
user_state.knowledge_level: Specific but narrow. The guest knows the listing details, the price structure, and their own schedule needs. They do not know what living there will actually feel like -- the experiencing self has no data, only the remembering self's forecast.
user_state.commitment_level: High. Submitting a proposal is the guest's first binding action. The sunk cost of the decision process (searching, evaluating, choosing) crystallizes here. The remembering self stores this as a decisive moment in the narrative.
user_state.data_available: Proposal terms (duration, days, pricing), time spent on proposal form, whether defaults were accepted or modified, whether messaging preceded the proposal.

reasons: The proposal form may break the emotional momentum by introducing unexpected costs or complexity -- the focusing illusion snaps when the guest sees the total price calculated

Miswanting: the guest may propose terms driven by the focusing illusion (longer duration because it 'feels like a better deal') that will not produce proportionally better experiences due to duration neglect

If the proposal process requires authentication, the user stories warn: 'Authentication should be invisible until it matters. Inline auth pop-up, not a full-page redirect. Users don't lose search context.' A full-page redirect creates a negative peak at the moment of highest commitment intent.
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'The proposal form to pre-populate with listing details so that I don't have to re-enter what the host already knows.' Kahneman Ch 38: 'The decision to get married reflects, for many people, a massive error of affective forecasting.' The proposal is the guest's 'marriage decision' -- driven by current positive affect and the focusing illusion rather than an accurate prediction of future experienced well-being.

key_quotes.quote: A well-structured proposal -- clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent -- activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.
key_quotes.relevance: The pre-populated proposal serves both parties' remembering selves: the guest stores a narrative of clarity ('I knew exactly what I proposed'), and the host receives a structured signal that reduces their anxiety. The structure compensates for the affective forecasting errors inherent in the proposal moment.

key_quotes.quote: The decision to get married reflects, for many people, a massive error of affective forecasting... The startling news of figure 16 is the steep decline of life satisfaction.
key_quotes.relevance: The guest creating a proposal is at peak anticipated satisfaction -- equivalent to the wedding-day spike in Kahneman's marriage graph. The platform should expect a similar decline as the lease progresses and the novelty fades. Design interventions should focus on managing the inevitable gap between anticipated and experienced utility.

negotiation.what_this_lens_reveals: Negotiation is where the guest's remembering self faces its first potential negative peak. The host counter-proposes (the journey map shows the host changing duration from 16 weeks to 10 weeks), and the guest must re-evaluate. Kahneman's prospect theory (referenced in Ch 35) shows that losses loom larger than gains -- a counter-proposal that reduces duration feels like a loss, even if 10 weeks at a better price is objectively favorable. The remembering self stores this as either 'we worked it out' (positive narrative) or 'they didn't want me on my terms' (negative narrative). The peak of the negotiation -- whether positive or negative -- will be stored disproportionately. The user stories analysis identifies that messaging is 'the highest cross-activation story in the list' because 'that's not just UX convenience -- it's the moment two strangers begin to trust each other through the platform.' The Two Selves lens adds: messaging during negotiation creates a human peak that can override the negative affect of a counter-proposal. If the host's counter comes with a warm message ('I'd love to have you, but 10 weeks works better for my schedule'), the remembering self stores the warmth, not the rejection. If the counter arrives as a cold, system-generated notification, the remembering self stores only the loss. Duration neglect applies to the negotiation timeline: whether the back-and-forth takes 2 hours or 2 days does not affect the remembered experience -- only the peak moment and the resolution (end) matter.

user_state.emotional_state: Anxious and loss-averse. The guest has committed emotionally (by proposing) and now faces the possibility of rejection or compromise. Kahneman's loss aversion means the pain of losing proposed terms (16 weeks reduced to 10) is felt more intensely than the pleasure of securing the stay. The remembering self is primed to store this as a negative peak unless the counter-proposal is delivered with human warmth.
user_state.knowledge_level: Good. The guest understands the listing, the original terms, and the counter-terms. They can make an informed decision. But their evaluation is distorted by the focusing illusion: they are currently focused on what was lost (6 weeks) rather than what remains (a confirmed stay).
user_state.commitment_level: High but fragile. The guest proposed and was counter-offered, which creates a sense of being 'almost there.' But the gap between proposal and counter can feel like rejection. The commitment holds only if the narrative remains positive.
user_state.data_available: Original proposal terms, counter-proposal terms, delta between them, time between proposal and counter, whether messaging accompanied the counter, whether the guest viewed the counter immediately or delayed.

reasons: Loss aversion: the counter-proposal feels like a rejection regardless of its objective reasonableness
The peak-end rule means the most emotionally intense moment of the negotiation defines the memory -- if that peak is the shock of seeing reduced terms, the narrative turns negative

Duration neglect means a fast counter (within hours) and a slow counter (days later) create the same remembered experience -- but the slow counter allows the negative affect to be rehearsed and amplified
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Messaging is the highest cross-activation story in the list. When a guest messages a host, that's not just UX convenience -- it's the moment two strangers begin to trust each other through the platform.' Kahneman Ch 35: 'Memories are all we get to keep from our experience of living.' If the negotiation memory is 'the host rejected my terms,' the guest may walk away. If the memory is 'we talked it through and found something that works,' the guest proceeds.

key_quotes.quote: When a guest messages a host, that's not just UX convenience -- it's the moment two strangers begin to trust each other through the platform. The platform is the medium. If the message goes well, the host is activated. If the guest already has platform history, the host is activated faster.
key_quotes.relevance: Messaging during negotiation creates a human interaction peak that the remembering self stores as the defining moment of the phase. Without messaging, the negotiation is remembered as a transactional exchange of numbers. With messaging, it is remembered as the beginning of a relationship.

key_quotes.quote: The experiencing self does not have a voice. The remembering self is sometimes wrong, but it is the one that keeps score and governs what we learn from living, and it is the one that makes decisions.
key_quotes.relevance: The guest's experiencing self during negotiation may feel fine -- the counter-terms are acceptable, the process is quick. But the remembering self is composing a story, and if that story is 'I was rejected,' the guest will not proceed or will not rebook -- regardless of how the experiencing self felt in the moment.

acceptance.what_this_lens_reveals: Acceptance is a peak moment that the remembering self will store permanently. Kahneman Ch 36 describes how 'we all care intensely for the narrative of our own life and very much want it to be a good story, with a decent hero.' Acceptance is the climax of the guest's booking narrative: the moment the story resolves. If this moment is anticlimactic (a dry confirmation screen, a transactional 'your proposal has been accepted'), the remembering self stores a flat endpoint rather than a peak. The journey map shows: 'The Guest clicks Accept Host Terms. A confirmation dialog appears: Yes, Proceed. After confirming, the proposal status updates to reflect mutual agreement.' This is purely transactional -- the experiencing self registers mild satisfaction, and the remembering self stores... almost nothing. The user stories analysis does not specifically address the acceptance moment, which is itself a signal: the acceptance experience has not been designed as a memorable peak. The Two Selves lens reveals this as a critical missed opportunity. Kahneman's vacation studies (Ch 36) show that 'the intentions for future vacations were entirely determined by the final evaluation -- even when that score did not accurately represent the quality of the experience described in the diaries.' Acceptance is the 'final evaluation' of the pre-lease journey. If it ends with a positive peak (celebration, human warmth, anticipation-building), the guest enters move-in with a positive narrative. If it ends flatly, the guest enters move-in neutral -- and neutral is fragile.

user_state.emotional_state: Relief and anticipation. The experiencing self feels the resolution of uncertainty -- the deal is done. But the intensity of this feeling depends on how the platform delivers the moment. Kahneman Ch 36: 'the emotion I felt about the lovers' reunion would not have changed if I had learned that they actually had a week together, rather than 10 minutes' -- the acceptance moment is about narrative resolution, not the details of the terms.
user_state.knowledge_level: Complete for the agreement. The guest knows exactly what they agreed to: dates, duration, price, rules. They have all the information needed to begin the lease.
user_state.commitment_level: Maximum. The guest has formally accepted terms and authorized payment. This is the highest commitment point in the pre-lease journey. The remembering self stores this as the decisive moment.
user_state.data_available: Acceptance timestamp, final agreed terms, time from proposal to acceptance, whether any messaging occurred during negotiation, payment authorization status, document delivery status.

reasons: The guest has formally committed -- withdrawal at this point requires active cancellation rather than passive exit
The narrative arc (search, evaluate, propose, negotiate, accept) has reached resolution, which the remembering self finds satisfying
Payment authorization and document delivery create structural commitment
dropout_risk.evidence: Journey map: 'Both parties have now reached agreed-upon terms. Split Lease generates and sends the lease documents to both Host and Guest.' Kahneman Ch 36: 'If the lover had come too late, La Traviata would have been an altogether different story.' The acceptance moment must land -- if documents are delayed, if payment fails, if the confirmation is unclear, the story's resolution is spoiled.

key_quotes.quote: A story is about significant events and memorable moments, not about time passing. Duration neglect is normal in a story, and the ending often defines its character.
key_quotes.relevance: Acceptance is the ending of the booking story. If it is memorable and positive, the guest enters the lease with a narrative that supports satisfaction. If it is forgettable, the guest enters the lease without a narrative anchor -- making them more vulnerable to the first negative experience they encounter.

key_quotes.quote: The intentions for future vacations were entirely determined by the final evaluation -- even when that score did not accurately represent the quality of the experience described in the diaries.
key_quotes.relevance: The acceptance moment is the 'final evaluation' of the pre-lease journey. It determines the guest's narrative entering move-in. A strong positive acceptance moment creates a halo that protects against early disappointments. A flat acceptance moment leaves the guest's narrative unanchored.

move_in.what_this_lens_reveals: Move-in is the single most consequential moment in the entire guest journey from the remembering self's perspective. This is where the peak-end rule collides with the focusing illusion at maximum force. Kahneman Ch 35: 'The global retrospective rating was well predicted by the average of the level of pain reported at the worst moment of the experience and at its end.' Move-in is almost certainly the peak -- either the highest positive peak (the space is better than expected, the host is warm, the key handoff is smooth) or the highest negative peak (the space does not match the photos, something is broken, the host is absent). Whichever it is, this moment will define the guest's memory of the entire lease. The journey map describes move-in as: 'First impressions, key handoff, settling in. Guest accesses House Manual for rules, guidelines, and check-in procedures. Reality vs. listing expectations.' The phrase 'reality vs. listing expectations' is precisely the gap between affective forecasting and experienced utility that Kahneman identifies. The guest's proposal was an affective forecast; move-in is when experienced utility begins. The user stories analysis does not specifically address move-in, which is a critical gap. The Two Selves lens reveals that move-in design should be treated as the most important moment in the entire guest journey -- more important than search, more important than the listing page, more important than pricing. Because the remembering self weights peaks and ends above all else, and move-in is the first (and often highest) peak of the actual lease experience, it has disproportionate power to determine whether the guest rebooks. Kahneman Ch 38 on adaptation: 'Adaptation to a new situation, whether good or bad, consists in large part of thinking less and less about it.' After move-in, the guest will adapt -- the experiencing self will settle into routine. But the remembering self captured the move-in moment and will use it as the reference point for the entire lease narrative.

user_state.emotional_state: Heightened sensitivity. Every sensation is being registered with maximum intensity because everything is novel. Kahneman Ch 38: 'thoughts of any aspect of life are more likely to be salient if a contrasting alternative is highly available' -- the guest is contrasting the new space with their previous living situation, with the listing photos, with their expectations. This contrast amplifies every positive and negative detail. The focusing illusion is at full strength: whatever the guest notices first (a stain, a beautiful view, a confusing lock) will define the space in memory.
user_state.knowledge_level: Transitioning from theoretical to experiential. The guest knew the listing from photos and descriptions; now they are experiencing the physical space. The gap between these two knowledge types (Kahneman's experienced vs. decision utility) is being revealed in real time.
user_state.commitment_level: Structurally maximum (lease signed, payment authorized) but psychologically vulnerable. The guest is committed on paper but their emotional commitment depends entirely on whether the move-in experience confirms or contradicts their affective forecast.
user_state.data_available: Check-in time, House Manual access, first message sent, any issue reports, time between arrival and first communication with host.

reasons: The peak-end rule means a negative move-in experience will define the entire lease memory -- the guest may endure the lease but will never rebook

The focusing illusion at maximum intensity: a single flaw noticed during move-in (unclean bathroom, different furniture than photos, confusing access) becomes the defining characteristic of the space in memory

Expectation gap: the affective forecast (built from listing photos and the positive acceptance narrative) collides with experienced utility. Any gap is experienced as a loss, and losses loom larger than gains
No platform mechanism currently exists to manufacture a positive move-in peak -- the moment is left entirely to chance and host behavior
dropout_risk.evidence: Journey map: 'First impressions, key handoff, settling in. Reality vs. listing expectations.' Kahneman Ch 35: 'If the objective is to reduce patients' memory of pain, lowering the peak intensity of pain could be more important than minimizing the duration of the procedure.' Applied to move-in: if the objective is to create a positive lease memory, engineering a positive move-in peak is more important than anything that happens during the subsequent weeks of the lease.

key_quotes.quote: If the objective is to reduce patients' memory of pain, lowering the peak intensity of pain could be more important than minimizing the duration of the procedure. By the same reasoning, gradual relief may be preferable to abrupt relief if patients retain a better memory when the pain at the end of the procedure is relatively mild.
key_quotes.relevance: Applied to move-in: if the objective is to create a positive lease memory that drives rebooking, engineering a positive move-in peak (warm host welcome, space exceeding expectations, smooth key handoff, a small personal touch) is more important than anything that happens during weeks 2-16 of the lease. The peak must be designed, not left to chance.

key_quotes.quote: Adaptation to a new situation, whether good or bad, consists in large part of thinking less and less about it. In that sense, most long-term circumstances of life, including paraplegia and marriage, are part-time states that one inhabits only when one attends to them.
key_quotes.relevance: After the move-in peak, the guest will adapt. The space will become routine. The experiencing self will be governed by daily activities, not by the space itself. But the remembering self captured the move-in moment and will use it as the anchor for the entire lease narrative. This is why move-in must be designed as a positive peak -- it is the only moment when the guest is fully attending to the space.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: Active lease is the domain of the experiencing self -- the guest is living moment-to-moment, and Kahneman's research shows that moment-to-moment well-being is determined by 'the current situation' (Ch 37): social contact, noise, stress, engagement. But the Two Selves framework reveals a fundamental tension: the experiencing self's daily well-being during the lease has almost no effect on whether the guest rebooks. The remembering self, which makes the rebooking decision, cares only about peaks and the end. This means the platform faces a paradox: it should optimize the experiencing self's daily well-being (because suffering is real) while simultaneously engineering memorable peaks and a positive ending (because these determine retention). The journey map details the daily mechanisms: Stays Manager, date changes, arrival notifications, cleaning photos, reviews, House Manual, messaging. These are experiencing-self features -- they make the daily reality better. But from the remembering self's perspective, they are invisible unless something goes wrong (creating a negative peak) or goes exceptionally right (creating a positive peak). Kahneman Ch 37: 'happiness is the experience of spending time with people you love and who love you.' The guest's daily experienced well-being is determined not by the platform but by their real-world situation -- their job, their relationships, their health. The space is merely the container. The platform's greatest leverage during active lease is not daily UX but the architecture of the ending. Kahneman Ch 35 on the colonoscopy study: 'gradual relief may be preferable to abrupt relief.' The lease should not end abruptly. The final days, the final stay, the final review -- these constitute the 'end' of the peak-end rule and must be designed with the same care as move-in. CRITICAL: The guest journey has no formal 'post_stay' or 'retention' phase. The end of active_lease IS the end of the experience. The remembering self's final impression of Split Lease is formed in the last days of the last stay. If the lease ends with administrative friction (unclear checkout, disputed cleaning, delayed deposit return), that becomes the END that the peak-end rule weights so heavily. If it ends with warmth (a host thank-you message, a smooth review exchange, a clear and positive offboarding), that positive end can override weeks of mediocre experiencing-self data.

user_state.emotional_state: Adapted and routine. Kahneman Ch 38: 'Adaptation to a new situation consists in large part of thinking less and less about it.' The guest is no longer thinking about the space or the platform except when directly interacting with them. Experienced well-being is determined by daily activities, not the lease. The experiencing self may be perfectly content, but the remembering self has nothing new to store -- until something goes wrong (negative peak) or the lease ends (the end). Late in the lease, as the end approaches, the emotional state shifts to anticipatory: the guest is thinking about what comes next, and this reflection activates the remembering self. The focusing illusion means whatever the guest is thinking about at lease-end (moving logistics, a dispute, a warm host relationship) defines the memory of the entire lease.
user_state.knowledge_level: Complete. The guest knows the space, the host, the platform, and the routines. Knowledge is no longer a factor in their experience.
user_state.commitment_level: Structurally committed (lease is active) but psychologically variable. A guest in week 8 of 16 may feel neutral -- neither eager to continue nor eager to leave. The remembering self has stored the move-in peak but has not yet formed a narrative about the experience as a whole. The narrative crystallizes only at the end.
user_state.data_available: Full behavioral data: payment history, stay patterns, date change frequency, communication volume and sentiment, cleaning photo consistency, review scores, House Manual access, issue reports, lease modification requests.

dropout_risk.level: low (during lease) / critical (at lease end for rebooking)
reasons: During the lease: structural commitment keeps the guest. Dropout means breaking the lease, which is costly and disruptive.

At lease end: the remembering self evaluates the entire experience using peak-end. If the peak was negative (bad move-in, a mid-lease dispute) and the end was negative (friction at checkout, unclear offboarding), the guest will not rebook regardless of how many weeks of adequate experiencing-self data the platform accumulated.

Duration neglect at lease end: the guest who had 14 good weeks and 2 bad weeks (including the final one) will remember the experience as worse than the guest who had 3 good weeks ending on a high note. The 14 good weeks literally do not count in the remembering self's evaluation.
The platform has no designed offboarding ritual. The journey map shows reviews and cleaning photos but no 'end of lease' ceremony -- no designed positive ending.
dropout_risk.evidence: Kahneman Ch 35: 'An inconsistency is built into the design of our minds. We have strong preferences about the duration of our experiences of pain and pleasure. We want pain to be brief and pleasure to last. But our memory has evolved to represent the most intense moment (the peak) and the feelings when the episode was at its end. A memory that neglects duration will not serve our preference for long pleasure and short pains.' Journey map Phase 5: 'At the end of each stay, both Host and Guest are prompted to review the experience' -- reviews are the closest thing to an end-of-lease ritual, but they are evaluative (backward-looking) rather than celebratory (narrative-closing). The platform needs a designed positive ending.

key_quotes.quote: An inconsistency is built into the design of our minds. We have strong preferences about the duration of our experiences of pain and pleasure. We want pain to be brief and pleasure to last. But our memory, a function of System 1, has evolved to represent the most intense moment of an episode of pain or pleasure (the peak) and the feelings when the episode was at its end. A memory that neglects duration will not serve our preference for long pleasure and short pains.
key_quotes.relevance: This is the central insight for active_lease: 16 weeks of adequate experienced well-being count for nothing in the remembering self's evaluation if the peak was negative and the ending was poor. The platform's entire retention strategy should focus on engineering a positive move-in peak and a positive lease-end experience. Everything in between is experiential -- real, but not retained.

key_quotes.quote: The intentions for future vacations were entirely determined by the final evaluation -- even when that score did not accurately represent the quality of the experience that was described in the diaries. As in the cold-hand experiment, right or wrong, people choose by memory when they decide whether or not to repeat an experience.
key_quotes.relevance: This is the mechanism of guest retention or churn. The guest's decision to rebook is 'entirely determined by the final evaluation' -- not by the sum of daily experiences. The platform must treat the end of active_lease as the single most important retention moment. A designed positive ending (host thank-you, platform acknowledgment, easy re-booking prompt, summary of the stay) can override weeks of neutral daily experiences.

key_quotes.quote: It is only a slight exaggeration to say that happiness is the experience of spending time with people you love and who love you.
key_quotes.relevance: During active lease, the guest's experienced well-being is determined by their real-world relationships and activities, not by the platform. The platform is the container, not the content. This means the platform's leverage during active lease is limited to preventing negative peaks (dispute resolution, issue handling) and designing the ending. The daily experiencing-self data is largely outside the platform's control.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The Peak-End Architecture -- move-in and lease-end are the only two moments that determine whether the guest rebooks, and neither is currently designed as a deliberate experience
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman Ch 35: 'The global retrospective rating was well predicted by the average of the level of pain reported at the worst moment of the experience and at its end.' The journey map describes move-in as 'First impressions, key handoff, settling in. Reality vs. listing expectations' -- a list of logistical steps, not a designed peak experience. The lease end is not described as a designed moment at all -- the journey map shows per-stay reviews and cleaning photos but no end-of-lease ceremony, no host thank-you prompt, no platform acknowledgment of the completed lease. The peak-end rule means these two moments have more power over rebooking than everything else combined, yet they receive the least deliberate design attention. This is the single largest retention opportunity in the guest journey.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Duration neglect as retention equalizer -- a 4-week lease remembered well produces more rebookings than a 16-week lease remembered poorly
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman Ch 35: 'Duration of the procedure had no effect whatsoever on the ratings of total pain.' Ch 36: 'doubling the duration of Jen's life had no effect whatsoever on the desirability of her life.' Applied to Split Lease: the guest who had a 4-week lease with a warm move-in and a positive ending will rate the experience higher -- and be more likely to rebook -- than the guest who had a 16-week lease with a mediocre move-in and an administrative ending. This has pricing and product implications: shorter leases with engineered peaks may produce better retention metrics than longer leases left to run on autopilot. The platform should not assume that longer leases are inherently more valuable for retention.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The Focusing Illusion Cascade -- whatever the guest attends to at each phase transition becomes the anchor for their evaluation of the next phase
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman Ch 38: 'Nothing in life is as important as you think it is when you are thinking about it.' In discovery, the guest attends to the first impression (focusing illusion sets the platform narrative). In search, they attend to the peak listing (focusing illusion sets the quality expectation). In listing_evaluation, they attend to whatever detail is most prominent -- photos, price, reviews (focusing illusion sets the space expectation). In proposal_creation, they attend to the terms (focusing illusion inflates the importance of price and duration). In move-in, they attend to the gap between expectation and reality (focusing illusion amplifies the gap). Each phase's focusing illusion creates the expectation that the next phase either confirms or violates. The cascade means that a design flaw in discovery can ripple through to move-in disappointment: if the first listing card was misleadingly beautiful, the guest's expectation cascade is set too high, and move-in becomes a negative peak regardless of the space's actual quality.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The Remembering Self as Retention Gatekeeper -- the rebooking decision is made entirely by the remembering self, not the experiencing self
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman Ch 36: 'The intentions for future vacations were entirely determined by the final evaluation -- even when that score did not accurately represent the quality of the experience that was described in the diaries. As in the cold-hand experiment, right or wrong, people choose by memory when they decide whether or not to repeat an experience.' The guest journey has no formal 'retention' or 'post_stay' phase. The rebooking decision happens after active_lease ends, when the guest is no longer on the platform. At that moment, the remembering self -- not the experiencing self -- makes the call. The remembering self has stored two data points: the peak and the end. All the daily experiencing-self data (the adequate weeks, the smooth payments, the functioning Stays Manager) is invisible to this decision. The platform must recognize that the rebooking decision is not a rational evaluation of the lease -- it is a memory retrieval. The question is not 'was the lease good?' but 'what does the guest remember?'

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Affective Forecasting Gap -- the guest's expectations at proposal_creation systematically overweight the novelty of the arrangement, creating a predictable disappointment trajectory
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman Ch 38 (marriage graph): 'The startling news is the steep decline of life satisfaction.' The guest creating a proposal is at peak anticipated satisfaction. Move-in is where the forecast meets reality. The predictable trajectory follows the marriage graph: elevated anticipation, initial excitement at move-in, rapid adaptation during active_lease, and a final evaluation driven by the end rather than the middle. The user stories note that 'proposal directly from the search card' is premature because 'they'll still open the listing before committing -- to check host reviews, credibility, full photos.' This is the user stories recognizing the affective forecasting risk: the more information the guest absorbs before committing, the smaller the gap between forecast and experienced reality. But even with full information, the focusing illusion guarantees some gap -- the guest will attend to the best features when deciding to propose and will attend to the worst features when arriving at the space.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The Amnesic Lease Thought Experiment -- if the guest would not rebook the lease without remembering it, the platform is serving the remembering self at the expense of the experiencing self
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman Ch 36: 'At the end of the vacation, all pictures and videos will be destroyed. Furthermore, you will swallow a potion that will wipe out all your memories of the vacation. How would this prospect affect your vacation plans?' Applied to Split Lease: if the guest knew they would forget the entire lease, would they still choose the same listing? The guest who searches for 'instagrammable' spaces (photo-worthy, narrative-rich) over 'livable' spaces (comfortable, functional, well-located for daily routine) is serving their remembering self at the expense of their experiencing self. The platform's listing page design, which leads with photos and descriptions (narrative-building tools), may inadvertently encourage this bias. A Two Selves-aware platform would balance remembering-self features (beautiful photos, unique spaces) with experiencing-self features (noise levels, commute times, daily convenience) -- information about what it is actually like to live there, day after day.

sources_consulted: kahneman-part5-two-selves.txt -- Part V of Thinking, Fast and Slow (Chapters 35-38). Ch 35: experiencing self vs remembering self, peak-end rule, duration neglect, cold-hand experiment, biological basis of memory distortion. Ch 36: life as a story, duration neglect in life narratives, amnesic vacations thought experiment, vacation rebooking governed by final evaluation. Ch 37: experienced well-being, Day Reconstruction Method, U-index, situational determinants of mood, $75K satiation level, attention as key to emotional state. Ch 38: focusing illusion ('nothing in life is as important as you think it is when you are thinking about it'), adaptation, miswanting, affective forecasting errors, marriage satisfaction decline graph. Applied throughout as the primary theoretical lens for understanding how guest memories of the lease experience -- not the experience itself -- determine retention.

user-stories-initial-analysis.md -- Rod's analysis of guest user stories. Key insights used: 'value before the ask' (peak-end implications for discovery), listing card enrichment (peak manufacturing during search), messaging before proposals (creating human interaction peaks in listing_evaluation and negotiation), authentication invisibility (preventing negative peaks at commitment moments), proposal pre-population (reducing affective forecasting errors), cross-activation through messaging (human peaks in negotiation). Note: this document focuses on pre-lease UX and does not address move-in, active_lease, or lease-end moments -- a gap that the Two Selves lens identifies as critical.

split-lease-journey-map.md -- Complete host and guest journey map. Used for concrete journey mechanics at each phase. Key observations: move-in is described as logistical steps rather than a designed experience, lease-end has no ceremony or designed positive ending, per-stay reviews provide the only structured ending ritual but are evaluative rather than celebratory, the Stays Manager and Date Change Tool serve the experiencing self but are invisible to the remembering self unless they fail.

inputs/journey-types.json -- Guest journey phase vocabulary (discovery, search, listing_evaluation, proposal_creation, negotiation, acceptance, move_in, active_lease). Confirms that the guest journey has no formal post_stay or retention phase -- the end of active_lease is the end of the experience as far as the platform's journey model is concerned. Insights about lease-end retention and rebooking decisions are mapped to active_lease and cross_phase_patterns.
